poem_title: TO A MOUNTAIN-DAISY, On turning one down, with the Plough, in April — 1786.
author: Robert Burns
poem_alt_title: On turning one down , with the Plough , in April — 1786.

lines.line_text: Thou's met me in an evil hour;
For I maun crush amang the stoure
To spare thee now is past my pow'r,

stanzas.stanza_text:
WEE, modest, crimson-tipped flow'r,
Thou's met me in an evil hour;
For I maun crush amang the stoure
Thy slender stem:
To spare thee now is past my pow'r,
Thou bonie gem.

lines.line_text: Alas! it's no thy neebor sweet,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Alas! it's no thy neebor sweet,
The bonie Lark, companion meet!
Bending thee 'mang the dewy weet!
Wi's spreckl'd breast,
When upward-springing, blythe, to greet
The purpling East.

Cauld blew the bitter-biting North
Upon thy early, humble birth;
Yet chearfully thou glinted forth
Amid the storm,
Scarce rear'd above the Parent-earth
Thy tender form.

lines.line_text: The flaunting flow'rs our Gardens yield,
High-shelt'ring woods and wa's maun shield,
But thou, beneath the random bield

stanzas.stanza_text:
The flaunting flow'rs our Gardens yield,
High-shelt'ring woods and wa's maun shield,
But thou, beneath the random bield
O' clod or stane,
Adorns the histie stibble-field,
Unseen, alane.

lines.line_text: There, in thy scanty mantle clad,
But now the share uptears thy bed,

stanzas.stanza_text:
There, in thy scanty mantle clad,
Thy snawie bosom sun-ward spread,
Thou lifts thy unassuming head
In humble guise;
But now the share uptears thy bed,
And low thou lies!

lines.line_text: Such is the fate of artless Maid,
Sweet flow'ret of the rural shade!
Till she, like thee, all soil'd, is laid

stanzas.stanza_text:
Such is the fate of artless Maid,
Sweet flow'ret of the rural shade!
By Love's simplicity betray'd,
And guileless trust,
Till she, like thee, all soil'd, is laid
Low i' the dust.

lines.line_text: Such is the fate of simple Bard,
On Life's rough ocean luckless starr'd!
Unskilful he to note the card
Till billows rage, and gales blow hard,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Such is the fate of simple Bard,
On Life's rough ocean luckless starr'd!
Unskilful he to note the card
Of prudent Lore,
Till billows rage, and gales blow hard,
And whelm him o'er!

lines.line_text: Such fate to suffering worth is giv'n,
Who long with wants and woes has striv'n,
By human pride or cunning driv'n
Till wrench'd of ev'ry stay but HEAV'N,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Such fate to suffering worth is giv'n,
Who long with wants and woes has striv'n,
By human pride or cunning driv'n
To Mis'ry's brink,
Till wrench'd of ev'ry stay but HEAV'N,
He, ruin'd, sink!

lines.line_text: Ev'n thou who mourn'st the Daisy's fate,
That fate is thine — no distant date;
Till crush'd beneath the furrows weight,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Ev'n thou who mourn'st the Daisy's fate,
That fate is thine — no distant date;
Stern Ruin's plough-share drives, elate,
Full on thy bloom,
Till crush'd beneath the furrows weight,
Shall be thy doom!
